Winner is whoever turns compute into intelligence first

Everyone got excited about the first $NVDA Blackwell chip made in the U.S. but truth is it still has to go to Taiwan & pass through $TSM for advanced packaging before it‚Äôs complete. 

Until we can handle that stage at home then it‚Äôs not full production but just the first step.

That would make personal plans the new default for coverage & turn platforms like Oscar into the infrastructure layer for how health insurance is bought & managed in the U.S.

Yesterday I did an interview with a journalist about what the next decade of the AI trade looks like. 

Every market cycle starts with abundance and ends with constraint. The AI trade is no different where each leg reveals the next bottleneck: 

‚Ä¢ Compute (2023‚Äì2025)

This is the silicon era where $NVDA, $AMD, $TSM & $ASML are building the new industrial base of the digital economy. Compute is capacity so whoever controls it owns time.

‚Ä¢ Power (2025‚Äì2027) 

Then comes power where $VST, $CEG, $NRG & $NEE is about how it‚Äôs delivered, scaled and managed. This phase is about generation capacity & transmission lines.

‚Ä¢ Cooling & Networking (2026‚Äì2028) 

This phase is about keeping GPUs connected and efficient. $VRT, $AVGO, $ALAB, $MRVL & $CRDO are scaling the plumbing that moves data and manages heat. Optical interconnects, switches,m and liquid cooling systems all converge here where the next speed limit is heat and bandwidth.

‚Ä¢ Data Movement (2028‚Äì2030) 

After the pipes are built, attention shifts to how information flows where $SNOW, $PLTR, $MDB, $NET & $ORCL are building the operating rails for AI workflows, moving unstructured data across every enterprise and every cloud. Intelligence becomes a utility.

‚Ä¢ Quantum & Energy Convergence (2030+)

Quantum expands the compute stack, sitting beside GPUs to solve the hardest optimization problems with $IONQ as my favorite name in the group. Nuclear gives the grid true baseload power by delivering the energy density needed to keep AI infrastructure running nonstop. So when you put it together its quantum breaks computational limits and nuclear removes power constraints. 

But this last stage of the AI trade has been bid up too quickly. It‚Äôs the frothiest pocket of the AI theme right now that‚Äôs priced for perfection before the infrastructure even exists. The timeline is real but the market has sprinted years ahead of it. 

Every leg of this cycle will have its winners but the edge comes from spotting the constraint before it becomes consensus.

$NBIS, $IREN, $CIFR & $CRWV are the GPU landlords turning megawatts into rentable compute. 

This phase marks the birth of the AI utility class where companies that sell compute the way traditional utilities sell electricity. 

Fits adjacent to the power stage.

$TSLA is leading the next leg of the AI cycle where this whole thing becomes very real with Physical AI.

The first phase was compute where everything lived inside the data center while the next phase is about intelligence moving into the physical world where machines, cars & robots that can see, think & act on their own.

Tesla is the clear category leader since Optimus, FSD & Tesla Energy are now part of one unified narrative of converting AI into motion and productivity.

China still controls almost all rare earth production & refining but the U.S. is starting to rebuild its own chain:

‚Ä¢ $UUUU separating oxides at commercial scale
‚Ä¢ $IPX developing new refining tech to lift throughput
‚Ä¢ $MP leading U.S. output & expanding into full-cycle processing
‚Ä¢ $CRML & $TMRC building integrated mining and refining capacity
‚Ä¢ $USAR & $IDR advancing early-stage exploration across key deposits
‚Ä¢ $AREC recovering rare earths from coal waste to speed domestic supply
‚Ä¢ $USAR & $IDR advancing early-stage exploration across key deposits

Rare earths decide who controls the inputs behind AI, energy & defense.

$TSM dropped a video from its Arizona fab showing $ASML EUV machines printing next-gen chips.

Every wafer that leaves that line runs through ASML proving the U.S. chip buildout still revolves around the same gatekeeper. 

ASML is still the AI kingmaker.

AI DATA CENTERS WILL USE 12% OF ALL U.S. POWER BY 2030

Every new AI data center is a power plant disguised as compute & the grid is quietly becoming the new bottleneck in AI scale.

The next trillion in market cap belongs to whoever controls the power that feeds the chips.

Totally normal and definitely not astroturfed.

6/6

The signal from the funding market and bank stocks was that they are worried the Fed drained too much liquidity from the system (QT), and it is not clear whether they appreciate it, the risk of another round of QE, or how to fix it.

4/6

Cash being parked in the New York Fed Reverse Repo Facility ( RRP) sink almost every day is now nearing zero. And, as the arrow below shows, it has really started diving toward zero several weeks ago.

The RRP is about ten years old. This facility allowed market participants to park cash at the New York Federal Reserve in exchange for competitive interest rates. That rate is currently set 25 basis points below the top end of the Federal Reserve‚Äôs target rate. Today, the target range is 4.00% to 4.25%, so the RRP rate is 4.00%.

The purpose of this facility is to drain excess funds from the financial system (that is, remove liquidity). When money is parked at the Fed, it cannot be re-lent, a process known as rehypothecation, thereby reducing liquidity in the financial system.

When RRP is declining, these funds are reintroduced into the financial system, thereby adding liquidity. When the facility‚Äôs usage hits zero, as it essentially has, then this ‚Äúliquidity pump‚Äù has run dry.

Who do you trust?

According to a Partnership for Public Service survey conducted in March 2025, only 33% of Americans say they trust the U.S. government, while 47% say they do not trust it. 

A Gallup survey conducted in July 2025 shows that only 28% of Americans have confidence in major U.S. institutions (a near record-low and the 4th straight year of sub-30%), and that U.S. trust in mass media is at a new low of 28%
